fields.body:
ITV has joined major Hollywood studios including Disney and Fox, two major Wall Street banks and the billionaire Walton family in a $1bn (£770m) investment to back an ambitious new video streaming service for mobile phones.

NewTV, the temporary name for the new venture, aims to win over the smartphone generation in the same way that Netflix has transformed traditional TV viewing.

It is being launched by Jeffrey Katzenberg, co-founder of DreamWorks – the creator of film hits including Shrek – with the former Hewlett-Packard and eBay boss Meg Whitman as chief executive.

NewTV has raised $1bn from a who’s who of entertainment partners including Disney, 21st Century Fox, the Hunger Games maker Lionsgate, NBC Universal, Sony Pictures, Viacom, which owns Paramount Pictures, and Warner Media. The Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba and the investment banks JP Morgan and Goldman Sachs are also backing the venture, along with Madrone Capital, an investment fund run by Rob Walton, the son of the Walmart founder, Sam Walton.

“NewTV brings together the best of Silicon Valley and Hollywood to create the first entertainment platform built for easy, on-the-go mobile viewing,” Katzenberg and Whitman said in a statement.

The new service, planned for launch next year, will aim to tap the talent and intellectual property of its entertainment partners to create top quality shows that will cost about $15m a season.

The venture is aiming for quality akin to a Netflix or HBO experience, not the traditional low budgets associated with mobile video entertainment. Content will be broken down into smartphone-digestible episodes of up to 15 minutes in length.

“We are already seeing tremendous interest from Hollywood’s top talent,” said Katzenberg, who last year said he had already spoken to big names including the directors JJ Abramsand Ron Howard, and the producer Jerry Bruckheimer.

Whitman added: “More so than ever, people want easy access to the highest quality entertainment that fits perfectly into their busy, on-the-go lifestyles.”

NewTV aims to launch with two subscription tiers similar to the US streaming service Hulu – one with advertising and one without.

ITV said it was joining the venture as part of the new chief executive Carolyn McCall’s strategy for the broadcaster to be “more than TV” and make more of its expansive studio production business.

“Global demand for high-quality entertainment continues to grow,” said Julian Bellamy, managing director of ITV Studios. “Being part of the start of this exciting new mobile platform offers ITV’s hugely talented and creative people around the world the opportunity to produce content in a way never seen before.”

NewTV is aiming to tap into the booming use of smartphones to watch video content. However, so far no venture focused solely on mobile has managed to make it work.

Verizon recently shut down its go90 mobile streaming service after it failed to prove popular.

The former Hulu chief executive Jason Kilar’s Vessel similarly failed, while Facebook Watch originally focused on short-form content but has more recently changed tack towards longer-form TV shows.

“We’ve seen it with sports and music that consumer viewing habits are continuing to change and mobile video consumption is where the growth is happening,” said Gareth Capon, chief executive of the video production platform Grabyo.

“Consumers want content on multiple devices and want the flexibility to choose when, where and how they watch. Established publishers have tried to do this but haven’t seen the success they probably would have liked, as many mobile-first offerings have lacked the qualities needed for mobile success.”

Disney and Rupert Murdoch’s Fox have invested ahead of their $71bn merger – as has Comcast, which is seeking to take over Sky – as media giants look to protect their businesses against the rapidly changing habits of modern viewers.

Related: Netflix has forever changed the way we consume television | Lanre Bakare

The race to own the streaming space is becoming increasingly complicated as Disney, Fox and Comcast also each own 30% of Hulu. Disney will own 60% of Hulu following its takeover of Fox, while it has been speculated that Comcast may sell its 30% stake to Disney rather than hold a minority position it can do little with.

If Comcast, which owns the makers of Downton Abbey and Made in Chelsea, succeeds in taking over Sky it will inherit the streaming platforms Now TV and Sky Go, which it could roll out internationally.

In addition, Disney is planning its own entertainment streaming TV service, to be populated with content spanning the Marvel superhero films, the Star Wars franchise, Pixar titles including Toy Story and The Incredibles and traditional Disney fare such as Frozen and Beauty and the Beast – and has pulled its content from Netflix in the US.

“We don’t consider this competitive with Hulu, or HBO, or Netflix, or the networks,” said Katzenberg. “It’s a completely different use case.”

fields.headline: ITV joins Hollywood giants to back video streaming service for mobiles
fields.standfirst: DreamWorks co-founder Jeffrey Katzenberg’s NewTV venture raises $1bn from Disney, Fox and others
fields.trailText: DreamWorks co-founder Jeffrey Katzenberg’s NewTV venture raises $1bn from Disney, Fox and others

webTitle: ITV joins Hollywood giants to back video streaming service for mobiles

fields.body:
As high street retailers struggle with store closures and bankruptcies, an online auctioneer is thriving.

John Pye Auctions operates a digital bootsale that helps clear stock from collapsed shop chains, closed down restaurants and failed manufacturers. On a Monday morning in August, a traffic jam at a secluded industrial estate in rural Staffordshire indicates that the firm is doing brisk business.

Hundreds of would-be buyers are flocking to a public viewing at John Pye’s Marchington warehouse to scour for bargain furniture, TVs, cars and even Christmas baubles at its latest sale.

The business also works with successful retailers, including John Lewis and Made.com, as well as several major pawnbrokers, to help clear unwanted stock and items returned by online shoppers that cannot be directly resold.

John Pye is having a good year. Sales are up by more than 35% in the first six months of 2018, year on year, and are expected to continue that trend in the next six months.

The company recently cleared hundreds of pieces of furniture from the collapsed Fabb Sofas and from two casual dining chains which have been closing outlets.

“We’ve had the best start to the year since the last recession in 2008,” says Sheldon Miller, business development director for the family-owned business.

Last year Pye’s profits more than tripled to more than £1.1m partly thanks to a government contract to sell off cars seized by the DVLA.

By midday in Marchington there are nearly 2,000 people bouncing on sofas, peering into fridges, kicking car tyres and poking around in boxes of assorted retail flotsam, from broken beds to computer games. After noting down the lot numbers, they then bid for the items online.

Related: The death of the department store, a place out of time | Jess Cartner-Morley

“There’s nothing you can mention we haven’t sold - except livestock,” says 87-year-old founder John Pye.

Pye began trading in 1946, helping people move home with a cart and former pit pony called Spanker. The auction business began as a way to clear belongings his clients no longer wanted and took off when he moved to the Corn Exchange in Nottingham’s Cattle Market in 1969.

He now presides over an empire with 22 sites, 13 of which are dedicated to selling cars, and six general viewing sites including one on Bond Street, in London’s West End, dedicated to selling luxury jewellery and art. There also a 315,000 sq ft site in Port Talbot, Wales. About 15 articulated lorries of goods arrive each day at Marchington alone, contributing to 30,000 lots a week across the business.

Pye put down his gavel 12 years ago, when his son took over and moved all the auctions online. In his heyday, Pye would be calling bids from just a few hundred professional dealers. Today the business has 275,000 registered bidders, 70% of whom are shopping for themselves.

Related: House of Fraser's Oxford Street store saved from closure

In Marchington, families with kids stop for a bacon sandwich in the coffee shop and vie for goods with landlords fitting out properties and small traders buying to sell on eBay or in a local shop.

“Every type of person you can think of buys here,” says Pye. “We have one dealer who has spent about £100,000 online with us and we’ve never seen him.”

Apart from the luxury items, nothing has a reserve price and items go for an average of 20% of their retail sale price. Everything is sold as seen and nothing can be returned so savvy bidders visit to check if their dream sofa has a missing leg. Pye doesn’t own the stock; it takes a cut from the sale price with the rest going back to the retailer.

Maxine Dolman, from Burton upon Trent, is a regular, having bought an John Lewis patio set from John Pye via a series of bids for a fraction of its retail price. “I got a table, a love seat, two footstools. I did buy a Vax that didn’t work and a three-legged sofa. You have to be careful as you can’t always see what works, but what a bargain if you get it right.”

Martin McMinn from Derby, who is visiting the showrooms for the first time, is disappointed that there are no Dysons. “There’s quite a lot of tat here and would I buy something with no guarantee? But my mate visits all the time and loves checking out the website.”

Even fans admit that any purchase is a gamble, but it hasn’t stopped John Pye selling boats, Formula 1 cars, perfume, fine wines, enormous machinery and even aeroplanes in the past. Earlier this year, the company auctioned off 486 wedding dresses after a chain went bust. It rigged up changing rooms and put on Prosecco for prospective buyers and cleared the lot for about 15% of its retail value.

As the retail closures mount up, Miller says he expects a busy end to the year.

“This is only the tip of the iceberg. Interests rates are going up and I suspect there is going to be double whammy with a squeeze on consumer spending. A lot of people are maxed out. It’s tough times on the high street.”

But he takes no pleasure from the problems retailers are currently facing: “We don’t want to see retailers going bust. We get more business as a supporter to retail clients. We want those ongoing partnerships.”

fields.headline: Bargain wedding dresses, TVs and antiques: John Pye sees soaring sales
fields.standfirst: Selling unwanted stock from closing stores has given the online auctioneer a boost
fields.trailText: Selling unwanted stock from closing stores has given the online auctioneer a boost

webTitle: Bargain wedding dresses, TVs and antiques: John Pye sees soaring sales
